stem: The nurse is evaluating a client with suspected neurological damage. For each physical exam finding, select whether it indicates an Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) lesion or a Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) lesion.

rows.text: Positive Babinski sign (toes fan upward in an adult).

rationale.correct: UMNs are in the brain/spinal cord; LMNs are the 'final common pathway' to the muscle. (r1 & r4) UMN damage removes the 'brakes' on the spinal cord, leading to high-tone (spasticity), high reflexes, and primitive signs (Babinski). (r2 & r3) LMN damage disconnects the message entirely, leading to flaccid muscles, wasting (atrophy), and no reflexes.
rationale.incorrect: Spinal shock can temporarily mimic LMN signs (flaccidity) immediately after an injury, even if the eventual result is UMN spasticity.
clinicalPearls: Conditions like Stroke and Multiple Sclerosis (MS) are typically UMN diseases. Conditions like Guillain-Barr√© and Polio are LMN diseases. ALS (Lou Gehrig's) involves both.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: Babinski is NORMAL in an infant but always ABNORMAL (UMN damage) in an adult.

mnemonic.title: U-P vs L-O-W
mnemonic.expansion: Upper = Up (Upward Babinski, Upwards reflexes/hyper, Upwards tone). Lower = Low (Low tone, Low reflexes, Low muscle mass).

reviewUnits.heading: Applied Neurological Assessment
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must differentiate findings to help localize lesions. UMN lesions are central (CNS); LMN lesions are peripheral (PNS) or in the anterior horn of the spinal cord.
